title: S3 bucket data at http://rockset-support.s3-us-west-2.amazonaws.com/ reveals user addresses based on latitudes and longitudes.
content:
<image_0>
{F930036}
Steps to reproduce:
1, Download the file in the bucket with the command:
Code 34 Bytes
1aws s3 sync s3://rockset-support .
Open the file labelled data.json.15.
For each line, there will be a set of latitudes and longitudes. Copy a single pair.
{F930037}
Open Google Maps, enter the coordinates and click search.
{F930058}
Impact
Specific user location information violates the privacy policy stated by Rockset for its users allowing both targeted phishing attacks and physical risk.

screenshots.image_0: At the s3 bucket located at http://rockset-support.s3-us-west-2.amazonaws.com/, a file was found called data.json.15that contains of interest latitudes and latitudes of user addresses.

steps: Download the file in the bucket with the command: `aws s3 sync s3://rockset-support .`
Open the file labelled `data.json.15`, copy a latitude and longitude pair, and search for it in Google Maps.
vuln_description: The S3 bucket at http://rockset-support.s3-us-west-2.amazonaws.com/ contains a file (`data.json.15`) with latitude and longitude coordinates that, when entered into Google Maps, reveal specific user addresses. This violates Rockset's privacy policy and exposes users to targeted phishing or physical risks.
reason: The vulnerability involves straightforward steps: downloading a publicly accessible file and using publicly available tools (Google Maps) to interpret the data. No complex interactions, state manipulations, or novel logic are required.
